titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bruce Davidson photographs, 1955-2008 RL.11753
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-10 09:05:46 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Bruce Davidson (b. 1933) is an American-born photographer, and a member of the Magnum Photo cooperative agency. Collection consists of 229 photographic prints, mostly black-and-white, with color work present in several series. Subjects range widely, with a focus on human interactions, minority and disenfranchised communities, urban street photography, and landscapes influenced by human activity. Locations include Chicago; Paris; England, Wales, and Scotland; Sicily and Venice; Los Angeles and the California Pacific Coast Highway; and New York City, including East Harlem, Central Park, the subway, and other locations. Also included is a large series of portraits chiefly of celebrities, and images deriving from commercial assignments. Several portraits of African Americans from Mississippi, South Carolina, and New York City were taken in 1962 while Davidson was documenting civil rights actions. Other short series feature nude female studies, French fashion shows, and scenes from the film production of Zabriskie Point by Antonioni. Sizes range from approximately 6x9 to 20x24 inches. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The prints are organized by bodies of work, in alphabetical order by series title. Within the series, prints are arranged in rough date order by year.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bruce Davidson (1933- ) is an American-born photographer and photojournalist. A member of the Magnum Photo cooperative agency since 1958, his photographs have been published and exhibited widely, and are part of major museum holdings around the world.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Images may only be used for educational, non-commercial purposes; any other use requires the photographer's permission.

The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Bruce Davidson photographs were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Bruce Davidson photographs, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Paula Jeannet and Alanna Styer, 2020.
Accession(s) represented in this collection guide: 2019-0064.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The images in this collection were taken by photographer Bruce Davidson over the course of his career, from 1955 to 2008. Genres include street photography, interiors, landscapes, and portraits, all offering a complex view into interactions between people, and between humans and natural and built environments. Most were shot in black-and-white with a large-format camera, though there are also chromogenic and dye transfer color prints in several series. Most of the series in the collection house a small selection of prints from each project; the largest series, Portraits, contains almost 50 prints.

Some of Davidson's earliest photographs were shot in Montmartre, Paris in the 1950s, where he documented the solitary life of the widow of an Impressionist painter. He later returned to Paris in 1962, 1999, and 2005. He traveled the streets of New York City in the 1960s, exploring life in the Lower East Side, East Harlem, and Central Park, and continued this work from the 1970s into the 2000s. There are several series exploring Los Angeles, dating from the 1960s to the 2000s, as well as a series of images taken in Chicago during a visit in 1989. A few images are from Venice and Sicily.

Also present is a large series featuring portraits of U.S. actors, authors, politicians, artists, a conductor, and a rock musician. This series contains the earliest work in the collection, several portraits taken in 1955 of an aging couple in Arizona. A separate series, Time of Change, contains three portraits of African American rural and urban citizens in Mississippi, South Carolina, and New York City, taken in 1962 while Davidson documented the civil rights and suffrage movements in those locations.

Other series in this collection feature images of people, animals, and landscapes in England, Scotland, and coal mining communities in Wales; portraits of passengers on the New York subways; and photographs taken at fashion shoots and at filming locations for Zabriskie Point. Also included is a series of images from commercial assignments and commissions (1983-1997).

Image titles were taken from the prints or from the Magnum Photos website; a few other titles and captions derive from donor notes. Prints with no known titles are noted as such. Significant markings on the prints are also noted, as are legacy identifiers, which include various alphanumberic codes assigned by Davidson, the Magnum cooperative, and a private collector.

The prints are unmounted and were created with traditional processes, chiefly silver gelatin (black-and-white) on paper, with large-format color work present in the Chicago and Subway series, and a few smaller color prints scattered in the Commercial and California series. Print sheet dimensions are given to the nearest 1/8 inch and include variations on 8x10, 8 1/2 x 11, 11x14, 16x20, and 20x24 sizes.
Many of the images in this collection were published in photobooks and in journalistic publications, and have been exhibited widely.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Davidson traveled to Los Angeles, California in 1964 and spent several weeks there, shooting street life, celebrities, landscapes, and architecture. He returned in 2008 to reconsider the city and its environment; these images are located in the series "The Nature of Los Angeles."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images in this series represent Davidson's commissioned work for a number of enterprises, including medical research organizations, Wells Fargo Bank, and the U.S. Air Force. These images are in black-and-white, with the exception of the Wells Fargo Bank series. When present, titles originate from captions on the prints. The donor's inventory served as the source for most of the subject notes; others are from inscriptions on the prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many of these images, taken in 1960s, were published in Davidson's photobook, England/Scotland, published by Steidl in 2006. Included in this series is a small group of images taken in coal mining communities in Wales in 1965. Although Davidson shot some images in this series on color film, the prints in this group are black-and-white. Titles are taken chiefly from the Magnum Photos website or from the prints themselves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This selection of black-and-white images, all shot in Paris during Davidson's return visit in 2005 and 2006, focus chiefly on Paris gardens, monuments, and public spaces. Photographs from this period, some of which are in this series, were featured in a 2007 exhibit titled "La nature de Paris." Titles, when present, are taken from the print versos or from the Magnum Photos website.

scopecontent.p: This series takes its name from a Bruce Davidson photobook by the same title published in 1995. Starting in the early 1960s and continuing into the 2000s, the photographer explored the human interactions and spontaneously formed and extraordinarily diverse communities of New York City's Central Park. Almost all titles are taken from the Magnum Photos website.

did.physdesc: 49 prints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One of the largest series in the collection, the portraits group begins with two of Davidson's earliest images in this collection, a couple in extreme old age, taken in Patagonia, Arizona in 1955. Other portraits include well-known composers, conductors, rock musicians, politicians, authors, and artists, most based in New York City. Almost all are black-and-white prints. Titles, when present, are taken either from the print versos, or from the Magnum Photos website. A few of these portraits remain unidentified. Many of these images can be found in the photobook titled Portraits, published by Aperture in 2005.

did.unittitle: Time of Change: Civil Rights Photographs
did.physdesc: 3 prints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series takes its name from Bruce Davidson's 2002 photobook. The three images of rural sharecroppers and urban residents were taken as Davidson documented civil rights events in Mississippi, New York City, and South Carolina. From the Magnum Photos site: "The period from 1961-1965 was the defining era of the American civil rights movement...By linking seemingly unrelated stories, Davidson shows us that there was more to the civil rights movement than the violent and racially-charged images we have so often seen. He has provided the viewer with an alternative reading of life in the North and the South, and through this promotes a reinterpretation of our understanding of equal justice and the ongoing struggle for an egalitarian future."

did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 11 inches (21.59 x 27.94 cm)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title source: Magnum Photos. From the site's caption: "On December 3rd, 1999 the fire in Worcester [Massachusetts] started with a candle in an abandoned warehouse. It ended with temperatures above 3000 degrees and the men of the Worcester fire department in a fight for their lives. The fire killed 6 men. The family of Jerry Lucey. From left: John, Jeremiah III, and Michelle. When Lucey was a rookie, he called the captain of a rescue truck and told him he'd heard the squad was looking for a new man. The captain had never heard of a rookie doing such a thing, but he took him on anyway. He admired Lucey's guts. 'You can teach any man to be a good fighter,' the captain said, 'but you can't teach a good attitude.'" Other legacy identifiers: DAB 00-4-63/7; 44434 [66]
